answers.text:
HI Emily,  
As you’ve already found, the KN has lots of resources on soliciting citizen engagement in budgets. Here are some examples of what cities have done after they get that input.  
The best practice case study of the City of Decatur, GA Budgeting Process which describes the steps taken to involve citizens in the budgeting process though focus groups, that resulted in the addition of “strategic linkages” to the budget document. Next, the city manager and department heads collaborated to create a budget that adhered to the city’s vision and the final report included “budget narratives” that explained the process and reasoning of the decisions.  
Documents include the:  
2010 ICMA Strategic Leadership and Governance Award Recipient: The Sound of the City- Decatur's Collaborative Budgeting Process  
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302249/2010_ICMA_Strategic_Leadership_and_Governance_Award_Recipient_The_Sound_of_the_City_Decaturs_Collabo 
City of Decatur’s Budget Narrative   http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/9154/City_of_Decaturs_Budget_Narrative 
Collaborative Budgeting Process  
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/20897/Collaborative_Budgeting_Process 
An article from PM magazine, Citizen- Based Budgeting provides an overview of the methodology including steps to be taken after collecting citizen input.   
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/6932/CitizenBased_Budgeting 
Tarpon Springs’s Strategic Budgeting Using Public Opinion Polling illustrates the City’s experience of integrating public opinion polls into the budgeting process where survey showed higher citizen satisfaction with services despite cuts.   
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/100361/Tarpon_Springss_Strategic_Budgeting_Using_Public_Opinion_Polling 
You may want to seek out more resources from the Documents section or Budgeting and citizen involvement topic pages of the Knowledge Network   
I hope this is helpful,  
Pooja   
International City/County Management Association  
Knowledge Network Intern  
pvarma@icma.org

author: Emily Jackson
text:
Hi-
I've read through a lot of posts with some great advice about how to facilitate and encourage citizen engagement in the budget process (online forums, extended budget hearings, more informal, town hall meetings, online suggestion boxes etc.), but what do you do with the information and input that you receive from your community?  How do you integrate public input into the development of budget recommendations?  And more importantly, how do you show the community that you've listened to them and that their input was valuable (or at least taken into consideration)?
Does anyone have any advice or best practices to share along these lines?
Thank you!
title: What to do once you have citizen input on the budget?
